prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author (the wife) is in the wrong in this situation. The scenario is that her husband set up his office in their bedroom, even though she suggested the basement. Now, when he's working from the bedroom, especially during conference calls, she can't do basic tasks like showering or chores because the kids can't disturb him. She works from home too and handles most of the housework and kids. She told him she can't guarantee silence if he stays in the bedroom, so he's upset.

First, I need to figure out if the wife is in the wrong. The key points here are about mutual respect and reasonable accommodations. The husband chose to work in the bedroom despite the wife's suggestion to use the basement. His job is mostly conference calls, which require quiet. However, by choosing the bedroom, he's limiting the wife's ability to use the space and manage the household. 

The wife's argument is that she's not at fault because he made the choice to work in a space that's causing conflict. The husband, on the other hand, might feel he has the right to work in a place of his choosing. But since the wife is also working and handling the domestic responsibilities, there's a balance of needs. 

The question is whether the wife is wrong for not keeping the husband undisturbed. The husband's work setup is affecting her ability to function. If he's in the basement, the problem would resolve itself. But he chose not to move, so the responsibility might shift to him. The wife is realistic about what she can promise regarding silence if he's in the bedroom. 

So, the answer likely leans towards the wife not being in the wrong (B) because the husband made the choice to be in a disruptive location despite the alternative. The wife can't be expected to manage everything while he's in the bedroom, and his decision leads to her being unable to perform necessary tasks. Therefore, the husband might be the one at fault for not considering their shared living space dynamics.
